title: Logos and Equipment List Somewhere Accessible
text:
Code
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo=TRUE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, dpi=60, out.width = "100%")
options(scipen=999)
options(knitr.kable.NA = '--') #'--'
options(knitr.kable.NAN = '--')


This here is a post showing where we are now keeping the company equipment details as well as the company logos. We need these things to be accessible to all team members from all repos so we have put them here since this is a public repo.
Here is the location of the equipment lists that we use in safety/field planning:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NewGraphEnvironment/new_graphiti/main/assets/equipment.csv


Code
readr::read_csv(
  url(
    glue::glue("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/{params$repo_owner}/{params$repo_name}/main/assets/equipment.csv")
  )
)|> 
  fpr::fpr_kable(font = 12)

Logos:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NewGraphEnvironment/new_graphiti/main/assets/logos
There are many — so here is a list of their names and locations online:


Code
file_names <- fs::dir_ls(
  glue::glue(here::here("assets/logos")),
  glob = c("*.png", "*.jpg", "*.jpeg"),
  recurse = TRUE
) 


tibble::tibble(path = file_names) |> 
    dplyr::mutate(path = stringr::str_replace_all(path, "/Users/airvine/Projects/repo/new_graphiti", "https://github.com/NewGraphEnvironment/new_graphiti/tree/main")) |> 
  fpr::fpr_kable(font = 12)

title: snake_case vs Everything_Else
text:
Code
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo=TRUE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, dpi=60, out.width = "100%")
options(scipen=999)
options(knitr.kable.NA = '--') #'--'
options(knitr.kable.NAN = '--')


Been preferring snakecase naming convention for all files and columns and variables for a long time for the following reasons:

It’s much easier to type. Reaching for the shift button is a pain.
Arguably easier to read. I find it easier to read snake_case than CamelCase.
Can make it easy to name things in a fashion that allows you to dissect what something is by the way it is named and allows automatic sorting to group similar things together. This is a good read - https://speakerdeck.com/jennybc/how-to-name-files-the-sequel . This pays homage to one of my favorite programmers right now who is Michael Sumner. His tag line on github is “no names have an anonymous function”.



Code
knitr::include_graphics("thumbnail.jpg")








Figure 1





Worth noting that all-rules-need-to-be-broken sometimes such as when you are naming chunks in Rmarkdown and likely Quarto too. It breaks our cross-references (ex see Figure 1) vs Figure 2) when we name our chunks with underscores in them. Fun fact. Good chat.


Code
knitr::include_graphics("all.jpeg")








Figure 2
